author: potuz
content: Hi, I'm trying to sell <https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2763> or gauge interest. I wonder if I could get a review of someone involved with pools? Perhaps <@784446040073175040> or <@636289909359116290> ? Some of the things that should benefit pools besides quick and cheaply compounding would be to be able to buy or gather trustlessly earnings from a validator that the pool runs but doesn't have the withrawal keys for example.

author: jcrtp
content: I think for large node operators (with a large number of validators), this option is attractive because it's essentially letting you "batch withdraw" in a sense, if that's what you want to do. For smaller node operators, I do have some questions though

author: jcrtp
content:
For reference, we have 322 nodes with a single validator and 57 with 2 validators right now - regarding this point:

> Validators can trustlesly sell their excess earnings, providing liquidity for small stakers without requiring them to either wait possibly months nor withdraw their stake. Thus this could in principle be a decentralizing force.

Walk me through what you had in mind for those users?

author: potuz
content: Well, the simplest situation is someone that holds a withdrawal key and does not run the node (like in a few pools) and wants to sell the future earnings of his validator, he can just delegate the validator to another pool managed validator. This can probably be setup with a contract in the EL after BLOCKHASH is available: you delegate your validator to a contract managed one, and that contract provides liquidity in the EL immediately. So you can continuously extract earnings without withrawing your validator.

author: jcrtp
content: We have kind of the reverse situation - our setup is all `0x01` based so there isn't really a withdrawal key, just a validator key and that's what those small node operators have

author: chris2_2_2
content: of course this is a common sense proposal to improve things. Some pools probably will use a liquidity pool to do so without this proposal.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Not currently running an eth2 pool though

author: jcrtp
content: I should also mention that we don't really have liquidity in the EL to provide, which is why I'm asking about this

author: potuz
content: I haven't implemented `0x01` yet cause this will depend on how it's done in the final Withdrawal spec. But if your node operators don't have the private key for the `0x01`address, then they won't be able to delegate. Whomever holds the private key will be able to delegate that validator

author: jcrtp
content: It all pretty much immediately gets vaccumed up by node operators in the queue and put to work on Beacon

author: jcrtp
content: The `0x01` address in our case is a unique smart contract on the EL per validator

author: jcrtp
content: It doesn't have a private key

content: Probably, we'd need some way of doing it with either the validator key or via a TX from the `0x01` contract address

author: jcrtp
content: And we'd need some kind of ETH reserve on the EL

author: jgm
content:
Wait, are prices going to skyrocket or collapse? ðŸ™‚

Bear in mind that the exit queue means that you're going to be exiting no more than 35K Ether per day (and that's being generous), which doesn't seem like it's going to be enough to create a significant dent in the price.  Note that miners are currently issued around 12K per day, and that's new issuance rather than movement of existing funds (which is what the majority of returns from exited validators will be).

content: issuance and supply will collapse post merge as little issuance plus no withdrawals

author: jgm
content: According to coinmarketcap daily volume for ETH is around 6MM, not sure that an additional ~20K per day will have a massive impact.  But I'll shut up about it now, because I don't pay enough attention to the markets to have a better view.

content: I tend to agree with Jim about exit volume being minor compared to current trading volume, but I know zero about market, from the point of view of the protocol I am more worried about the user experience and network congestion because of validator rotation, than about price.
